toolkit-items.description:
Debugging HTML5 creatives is easy with built in browser development tools. All major browsers provide a developer inspector of some sort. Most can be accessed while on a page by right clicking and choosing 
"inspect element"
or via the menu options at the top. Debugging allows you to view the html structure of your creative, view and adjust CSS to tweak visual elements, as well as view network activity, console logging, and performance monitoring.

When it comes to debugging a mobile site or ad, you don’t have easy access to an inspector tool like you do on a desktop. Fortunately Chrome, Safari and Firefox all offer remote debugging over a USB connection to your desktop.

Check out the resources section for additional information and links from across the web.

quick-start.description:
Here’s how to quickly get testing with USB Debugging.

Get started on Chrome for Android by following instructions to enable USB debugging and connect your phone to your computer. Be sure to visit chrome://inspect and enable Discovery of USB devices.

Send a Studio preview to your phone so it opens in either the Chrome web browser or the Creative Preview app.

When visiting chrome://inspect you should now see your Device and any open tabs. Simply select inspect on Studio’s preview tab and you’ll be able to fully view and debug your creative as if on your desktop.

toolkit-items.description:
File size best practices for compressing images, optimizing code, and reducing file size

A common complaint in the Flash vs HTML5 debate is that HTML5 Creatives are really heavy in terms of file size. The reason for this misconception is because Flash is an application that not only handles the creation of ads, but also the compression of them.

“HTML5 Creatives”, on the other hand, commonly refers to ads created with the programming languages HTML, CSS, and Javascript. HTML5 Creatives provide many opportunities to compress your files.

Many of the tips provided can be implemented in under 15 minutes. The payoff is that a well-compressed HTML5 Creative will perform much better than a Flash Creative.

quick-start.description:
Google Web Designer (GWD) is an application specifically made for HTML5 ad development by Google, and is a great HTML5 alternative to developers that are only familiar with Flash. GWD has built in compression for images and code, Google web font support, SVG support, CSS animation support, etc. Additionally, it is fully integrated with Studio.

GWD is highly recommended above anything else when developing ads. More information on GWD can be found in the GWD Help Center.

Total File Size vs. Compressed File Size

The total file size (‘Raw File Size’) of your Creative can be viewed in DoubleClick Studio here. In Google Web Designer, you can view size of your Creative in the Publish panel. Google Web Designer compresses Creatives with gZip.

To determine your Creative’s compressed size, simply download a free copy of gZip, compress them on your local workspace, and inspect the file size.

Depending on the Publisher’s ad server, they will be calculating the compressed size of your Creative. Always double check with your Publisher to be sure.

What is a good baseline for HTML5 Creative file size?

It’s essential to understand your Publisher’s ad serving specifications prior to building your Creative. However, many Publishers follow the IAB recommendation of 35KB (compressed) Initial Load for the Creative and 100KB for total Creative size. Initial Load refers only file size of the .html file in the Creative, not the Enabler, Javascript, CSS, or other image files, but again, check with your Publisher to understand their guidelines to be sure.

More info about the IAB’s recommendations can be found here (page 8/9 here) and DoubleClick’s recommendations here.

How much does DoubleClick Enabler add in file weight?

As of April 2015, the Enabler adds approximately ~75KB (~25KB when gZipped).

link.title: How to Check Your File Size

quick-start.description:
Polite loading delays the loading of additional creative assets (like images and video) until the parent page has finished loading. This is different than ‘initial load’, which only refers to file size of the .html file in the Creative. It is helpful to implement the code for polite loading because many publishers have different specs for initial load versus the complete load size. More information about polite loading can be found here.

Check with the Publisher to understand their HTML5 specs for Rich Media ads because they are typically different than Flash-based specs. They may or may not count file size based on the compressed gzip format and will rather count the raw file size. Also, individual publisher specs differ from IAB specs depending on placement, ad type, etc. so they may allow more or less leeway in build specs. Publishers may also limit specs for animation and video play time.

Before attempting to reduce your image size, first determine if an image is even necessary as many things can be created with pure CSS. Here are some questions to ask before saving an asset as an image:

Is the graphic a gradient or a solid color?

Consider creating the image with just CSS3 to both improve the quality and reduce file size.

  • CSS3 Gradient Generator

Is the image comprised of solid colors or a vector?

Use SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) whenever possible instead of an image. Images are pixel based (“raster”) and may add some overhead in file weight. In contrast, SVGs are point-to-point based graphics (“vector”) and can greatly reduce file size.

  • W3School's SVG Tutorial
  • How to Use SVGs
  • Compressing SVGs

Does your Creative use multiple icons?

Use icon fonts whenever possible instead of an image for icons, images are pixel based and may add some overhead in file weight. Icon fonts are actually regular fonts and can be used in the same way as any other font in HTML. They are vector based as well. Custom icon fonts are relatively quick to create and implement.

  • Icomoon Icon Font Creator
  • NounProject: an affordable resource to gather SVG icons for your icon font

Are you using JPGs or PNGs in your project?

If pixel based images are required, compress them as much as possible while keeping quality. Many people are already familiar Photoshop’s Save For Web, but there are other online tools that can compress an image even further while retaining quality.

  • TinyPNG: Online PNG Compressor
  • TinyJPG: Online JPG Compressor

Consider using CSS3 animations (transitions/transforms) instead of Javascript for animations. CSS transforms use the GPU instead of the CPU for rendering animations so it helps with performance and preserves file size.

Refrain from using JavaScript libraries/frameworks that use the setInterval JavaScript method for animations, and if hand coding then do not use the setInterval method. This method uses up a lot of the browser’s resources and affects performance, and it requires a decent amount of code. If JavaScript animations are mandatory, then consider using the requestAnimationFrame method, it is specifically made for animations.

  • Using requestAnimationFrame
  • CSS vs Javascript Animations

Before uploading your CSS files to Studio, consider minifying your CSS with an Online CSS Minifier.

Are you using jQuery?

Don’t use jQuery in your HTML5 Creatives. jQuery is not recommended because it adds unnecessary file weight (~75k) even though the majority of the jQuery library is not utilized in a Creative. Consider using pure Javascript with this guide, or using Zepto.js if necessary.

Are you using a Javascript Framework?

Ask yourself if it is completely necessary to have them in your Creative. Consider taking pieces out of the framework and utilizing them in your main Javascript file to reduce overhead.

Are you targeting code for specific devices/browsers?

Ensure your code is written for devices/browsers specified, no need to add code for non-supported devices/browsers.

  • Browser and device support for DoubleClick Studio
  • Can I Use: Up to date browser support for JS and CSS properties

Compressing Javascript

GWD natively minifies files, so if you’re using GWD no minification is necessary. Otherwise,there are online tools that will remove comments and extra whitespace from your Javascript. It’s a best practice to keep a version of your uncompressed Javascript file locally on your computer for later reference.

Keep in mind that in DoubleClick Studio, JavaScript files require a .js extension, not .min.js. If you minify JavaScript files, you can't add tracking easily. If the client requests minifying, add tracking first and minify the .js file later.

If you are using a font other than the standard web fonts, consider using Google fonts. Google has a large library of fonts which can all be used for free. In order to reduce file size, be sure to only request the characters you need from the font vs. the entire typeface. This is called Font Subsetting.

  • Optimizing Font Requests

pro-tips.description: Google Web Designer automatically adds appropriate browser prefixes to any animation or elements constructed in the Design panel.
Avoid adding browser prefixes to every single CSS3 property. This will only bloat your CSS and file size. Double-check Can I use? for the specifics on browser compatibility

quick-start.description:
Some CSS3 properties are not yet standarized across all modern browsers. As a result, Vendor (or Browser) Prefixes are needed to ensure browser compatibility. These prefixes are:

-moz-/* Firefox and other browsers using Mozilla's browser engine */
-webkit-/* Safari, Chrome and browsers using the Webkit engine */
-o-/* Opera */
-ms-/* Internet Explorer (but not always) */

In use, this would look something like:

.example {
-webkit-transform: rotate(30deg); /* Chrome <36, Safari 5.1+, iOS, Android =<4.4.4 */
-ms-transform: rotate(30deg); /* Internet Explorer 9 */
transform: rotate(30deg); /* Internet Explorer 10, Firefox 16+, Opera 12.1+ */
}

To understand which browsers are compatible with which properties, be sure to consult Can I Use? as well as determining Linkwhat browsers DoubleClick Studio supports.

toolkit-items.description:
Your HTML5 Creatives have the ability to run across many screens, be it Desktop Websites, Tablet/Mobile Websites or Tablet/Mobile In-App. All at the same time! This can be a powerful thing, especially considering that behind the scenes an In-App behaves differently from a Website.

Let’s take a quick step back... HTML5 is the language of the Web, but an App is the language of, well, the phone it’s on! So when you put a HTML5 creative inside an app it needs some ‘Magic’ to make them talk the same language. This ‘Magic’ is called MRAID, but luckily for us the DoubleClick HTML5 Enabler does all this for us. So we can just focus on implementing this correctly.

In-App creatives can load in the background, use the Enabler’s Visibility check to make sure users can see your HTML5 In-app ad before loading further, animation or playing any video.
Don’t add a close button in your In-App Expand creatives, Studio will do this for you.
Make use of the Enabler’s Mobile orientation functions, and adjust your creative’s orientation accordingly.

quick-start.description:
Follow our In-Page Build guide to start make your standard banner, with a few lines of code you’ll be up and running.

In-Page or In-App formats can be chosen depending on where the creative will be trafficked

The Expanding creative build has a few extra steps and checks to watch out for.

Check the sequence of expand events outlined the build guide is correct, look out for 'requestExpand' and 'finishExpand' calls

We won’t always know the size of the screen we are looking to fill, there are alot of different mobile phone sizes out there!

When setting up an In-App Interstitial creative use the Flex by Flex size, and when setting up an In-App expand creative be sure of use the expand to fullscreen guide.

Your Creative will run in a lot of places, so it’s important we test them in all these places. For instance, your desktop browser may run the creative differently then your mobile browser, and your In-App creative may behave in the different way then your web creative.

Studio provides the ability to preview using your desktop, scan a QR code to preview on your mobile, or even push your creative to preview inside an Android App.

toolkit-items.description: CSS has the ability to detect to a browser’s screen size, pixel-density, and device orientation (amongst other properties) with the @media rule

links.title: Media Query Properties Explained in Detail
9 Basic Principles of Responsive Web Design

pro-tips.description: The @media rule is compatible with all modern browsers

Most developers put their media queries at the very bottom of their CSS and place all their media specific CSS rules within one @media rule vs multiple @media rule for the same screen size interspersed throughout their CSS.
Avoid bloating your CSS with too many media-queries. It’s best to try and accomplish the most CSS styling with the fewest media queries
If you are only developing one creative for a static size (ex 300x250) then media queries will not be necessary for your creative.

quick-start.description:
CSS has the ability to detect to a browser’s screen size, pixel-density, and device orientation (amongst other properties) with the @media rule. The format includes a rule that when true, applies specific CSS to an element(s). For example:

.container {
 background: red;
}

@media (max-width: 768px) {
 .container {
  background: blue;
 }
}

@media (max-width: 480px){
 .container {
  background: black;
 }
}

In the example above, if a browser is wider than 768px (most desktop browsers), the .container element will be red. If the browser is between 768px and 480px wide (most tablets oriented to portrait), the .container element will be blue. If the browser is 480px or smaller (most phones oriented to portrait), the .container will be black.

Media queries are particularly useful for making your full screen Creatives look great on all browser sizes. Another advantage for media queries is for when you have multiple sized Creatives, but only want to maintain one local CSS file. A complete explanation of the @media rule, and it’s properties, can be found here: http://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css3_pr_mediaquery.asp.

Landscape vs. Portrait

In addition to Media Queries detecting a device’s orientation, the Double-Click HTML5 SDK has the ability to do so as well. More information about the getOrientation() method can be found here and a video tutorial can be found on the Rich Media Help Center.

toolkit-items.title: Detecting Browser Size with CSS Media Queries

toolkit-items.description:
The Google Swiffy tool can elegantly convert your Flash files to HTML5. DoubleClick Campaign Manager and DoubleClick Bid Manager implement Swiffy to allow Media Agencies to convert basic Flash built creatives into HTML5, and Creative Agencies can use Swiffy to convert animation built in Flash.

and now the caveat… Unfortunately, for now, when it comes to Rich Media Swiffy will not convert it. What it can do is convert bits of it!

Let’s imagine we have a typical Flash creative, consisting of 80% animation and 20% logic/code/components...etc. This logic can be rebuilt in HTML5, and then instead of trying to re-building / replicating the Flash animation we can just move it to a separate Flash file and convert this using Swiffy. Allowing designers to continue using Flash while they learn new HTML5 tools like Google Web Designer.

pro-tips.description: Think of Swiffy as a short term tool solution, we don’t want to use Flash to do animation forever.
Remember, Swiffy can not be used to directly convert Rich Media directly.

quick-start.description:
Upload your SWF file into the Swiffy converter, and right click to save the new HTML5 conversion.

You could also install the Swiffy Adobe Flash Extension to export as HTML5 directly from Flash
